abstract.p: Prof Robert L Beschta letter says non-native species should be eliminated in restoration of native forests after fires (S)

block.p: This year, a staggering six million acres of public land in the West has burned in a single fire season (news article, Sept. 13). This year, a staggering six million acres of public land in the West has burned in a single fire season (news article, Sept. 13). For decades, federal agency responses to burned-over lands have involved a rush to re-establish vegetative cover. Thus, non-native plant seeds have been distributed over large areas, supposedly for the purpose of controlling erosion.

This approach is counterproductive. Recovery of most native forest species can quickly provide ground cover, and new research shows that seeding exotic plants has long-lasting impact on native biodiversity and structure of Western forests.

Scientists are increasingly alarmed at the spread of non-native plants in the United States and worldwide. It is time that federal land management agencies address these concerns by eliminating the use of non-native species in fire restoration.
ROBERT L. BESCHTA Corvallis, Ore., Sept. 13, 2000
The writer is emeritus professor of forest hydrology, Oregon State University.
